items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources, Instruction and, Juan Cruz, PrincipalSUBJECT:Yerba Buena High School PresentationThe Board presentation will focus on the third goal from our Single Site Plan for Student Achievement:  Continue to support a positive school climate and increase the daily student attendance.  We intend to close the achievement gap beginning with students attending class on a regular basis.  Students that do not attend their classes on a regular basis fall behind and jeopardize their graduation.  We have taken a comprehensive approach to developing a positive school climate, minimize the loss of ADA, and finally recover lost ADA.
items.item_text: Yerba Buena High School Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Juan Cruz, Principal
items.item_text_raw: 9.01 Yerba Buena High School Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Juan Cruz, Principal

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Language Minority ProgramsSUBJECT:Vietnamese Language Textbook Presentation The Vietnamese 1 for Vietnamese Speakers (V1VS) book was developed by District staff based on the need of the students.  The V1VS course was modeled after Spanish 1 for the Spanish Speakers course. V1VS is a college preparatory World Language course.  Students take this course to fulfill the foreign language requirements for high school graduation and for UC and CSU requirements.Unlike other languages offered in the District such as Spanish, French, or German where materials are abundant, the Vietnamese teachers needed to start from the very beginning.  Competitive grants were written to seek funds for textbook development.  Title VII and Refugee Children Supplemental Grants fund the textbook project.FISCAL IMPACT:Curriculum development & technical support:  $29,132.Printing cost for 1,000 copies: $ 61,842.FUNDING SOURCE:Refugee Children Supplemental Grant RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees continue to support the VVS Program as it helps students fulfill the foreign language requirements for high school graduation and UC and CSU requirements.
items.item_text: Vietnamese Language Textbook Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Language Minority Programs
items.item_text_raw: 9.02 Vietnamese Language Textbook Presentation - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Language Minority Programs

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction and, Nguyet Dinh, Administrator of Language Learners Supplementary EducationSUBJECT:Master Plan for English Learners (ELs) PresentationThe Master Plan for English Learners (ELs) was approved by the Board of Trustees in 2004. Based on the educational needs and achievement level of our ELs, the plan needs to be revised to incorporate the newest research based strategies on teaching and learning that will help our students succeed. This plan also aligns with the District’s Program Improvement Plan currently being implemented in the District.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the revision of the Master Plan for English Learners (ELs).

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Tim Nguyen, Coordinator of English Language Learners Supplementary EducationSUBJECT:Amend Date for 2010 Summer School ProgramOn January 21, 2010, the Board of Trustees approved the 2010 Summer School Program.  In the memorandum, it was stated that the legal observance of Independence Day would be on Friday, July 2, 2010.  California Education Code ยง37220(b) states:When any of the holidays on which the schools would be closed falls on Sunday, the public schools shall close on the Monday following.Consequently, the January 21, 2010, Summer School Program memorandum should be amended to state that the legal observance of Independence Day will be Monday, July 5, 2010.FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the amended 2010 Summer School Program as indicated herein, and that the Interim Superintendent be authorized to make modifications as needed.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Approve Adult Education Summer School ProgramEast Side Adult Education will offer limited summer courses for seniors (Class of 2010) who have earned a minimum of 210 credits and need 10 credits or less to graduate.  These course offerings will provide senior non-grads with the core academic courses required to complete graduation requirements for summer graduation.1 section of Economics ( one section each semester)1 section of Government ( one section each semester)1 section of English 21 section of GeometryClass Schedule1st Semester June 21 – July 22nd Semester July 12 – 238:00 am–12:50 pm  Monday - Friday All classes will be offered at the Independence Adult Center.FISCAL IMPACT:$ 20,890.FUNDING SOURCE:Adult EducationRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Adult Education Summer Program for senior non-grads.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and InstructionSUBJECT:Receive the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2010 through March 31, 2010 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)BACKGROUNDAs a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers. Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the Governing Board and the County Superintendent of Schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from January 1, 2010 through March 31, 2010.  FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Senate Bill 6 (Williams)State Instructional Materials AllocationDistrict Instructional Materials BudgetOther Categorical funds as AppropriateRECOMMENDATION:The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the first Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering January 1, 2010 through March 31, 2010, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_text: Receive the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2010 through March 31, 2010 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727) - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction
items.item_text_raw: 9.07 Receive the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2010 through March 31, 2010 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727) - Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Cathy Giammona, Interim Associate Superintendent, Human Resources, Instruction, and Vicki Ponticelli, Coordinator of Testing, Evaluation and ResearchSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action regarding the Comparison of Educational Models on Calero PresentationThis is a presentation comparing educational models for Calero. Four years ago East Side Union High School District began to explore the possibility of opening its own community day school. The financial situation of our District has drastically changed and it is necessary to explore alternative models. This presentation will discuss the pros and cons of opening a Community Day School and compare it to an educational model that encompasses a Continuation School, Independent Study Program, and a Post Senior Program for our severely disabled students.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve a multi-school model for the Calero property.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and PlanningSUBJECT:Approve Proposed Modernization Plan for Calero High SchoolThe Board of Trustees approved the purchase of Calero School in 2008.  The intent of acquiring the school was for the District to continue providing quality programs for District students.In order to provide the necessary classroom spaces, construction modernization will need to occur to accommodate any Board approved educational programs. The scope of work for the modernization plan will include demolition, interior renovations, and site work.  The scope of work will be within the budget presented to the Board in February, 2009.The Facilities Bond Team will be present to answer questions from the Board of Trustees.FISCAL IMPACT:$9.5 MillionFUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed   modernization plan for Calero High School and for the administration to   proceed with the modernization efforts as appropriate.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT AMENDEDTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve an Agreement with Tramutola and EMC Research, for the Provision of Consultant Services and Conducting a Survey Regarding Possible Parcel Tax to be placed on the November 2010 BallotEast Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into an Agreement Tramutola and EMC Research, for the Term of April 16, 2010 through and including December 31, 2010 for the Provision of Consultant Services and Conducting a Survey Regarding Possible Parcel Tax to be placed on the November 2010 Ballot.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.Contractor will provide consulting services to assist the District in conducting a poll and evaluating the data that is gathered to determine whether it is feasible to move forward with a Parcel Tax Initiative to be place on an upcoming election ballot.  The District does not currently possess the skills or the resources to conduct such a poll.Selection Process Five (5) Consultants were solicited to participate in providing the District with a Proposal.  The consultants were selected based on their knowledge and experience within the District or surrounding area. On Monday April 12, 2010, all five (5) consultants were interviewed and their written proposals were accepted. The interview panel consisted of Dan Moser, Interim Superintendent; Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business Services; and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator.  Each Consultant was rated based on their responses to the questions that were in the letter that was provided to them from the District.  The questions asked of each consultants addressed the following areas: 1) Fee Schedule and all costs associated with the work to be performed; 2) Experience in consulting with urban school districts of similar size where parcel tax initiatives were placed on a ballot and passed or failed; 3) Description of their strategy that they would propose for a successful passage of a parcel tax at East Side Union High School District, including how they would include different stakeholder groups; 4) How they would address the diverse population; 5) Explanation of all proposed elements and the associated costs; 6) Provide detail list of all subcontractors to be used; 7) Provision of “other” information they felt relevant to assist the District in their decision. Each question was worth 10 points (5 points for the interview and 5 points for their proposal) for a maximum score possible of 70 points per reviewer for a total maximum score of 210. Below is how they scored:ConsultantDan MoserJerry KurrDonna BertrandTotalTramutola 685664  188   EMC Research (polling firm only)665468188TBW&B575255164Greg Bregman & Associates (polling firm only)504852150Dale Scott565454164Some consultants were strictly polling firms and others were full service providers.  The polling firms only are indicated below.  4 out of the 5 proposals submitted were in the traditional way, primary consultant who subcontracts out for the polling and research services.  The fifth one was a non-traditional proposal that included no fees upfront with the exception of an optional cost for a color informational mailer. However, the costs would be paid only if the Parcel Tax passed. If the Parcel Tax passed their proposal included reimbursing them all of the costs to do the survey and consulting prior to the decision and then they would be given a set “Financial Advisory Fee” for each year the Parcel Tax is in effect.  FISCAL IMPACT:$21,000 for Tramutola$30,600 for EMC ResearchFUNDING SOURCE:General FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees Approve an Agreement with Tramutola and EMC Research, for the Term of April 16, 2010 through and including December 31, 2010 for the Provision of Consultant Services and Conducting a Survey Regarding Possible Parcel Tax to be placed on the November 2010 Ballot.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentSUBJECT:Discussion and/or Action Regarding Input from Community Meetings Concerning Proposed Layoffs and Budget ShortfallAs of Friday, April 9, two of the four planned community meetings regarding the proposed layoffs and the budget shortfall for the 2010-11 school year have taken place.  Parents, students, and staff attended the community meetings at James Lick High School and W.C. Overfelt High School and expressed their concerns and fears about the proposed layoff of student support staff .  Parents from the James Lick High School English Language Advisory Council presented a petition and letter signed by 270 parents requesting the district find alternatives to the proposed layoffs.The two remaining meetings will take place at:6:30 p.m., Monday, April 13, at Oak Grove High School6:30 p.m., Wednesday, April 14, at Silver Creek High SchoolFISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:None

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Carl D. Perkins 131 Grant 2010-2011 Grant Application for East Side Union High School DistrictOverview:The East Side Career Technical Education Program includes the Andrew Hill Multimedia Academy, Andrew Hill Culinary Arts Pathway, Andrew Hill Biotechnology Academy, Andrew Hill Health/Nursing Academy, Andrew Hill Green Occupations Academy, Andrew Hill Public Services Academy, Mt. Pleasant Manufacturing Academy, Mt. Pleasant Green Remodeling and Construction Academy, Mt. Pleasant Animation Pathway, William C. Overfelt Early Childhood Education Academy, William C. Overfelt Green Career Academy, William C. Overfelt Multimedia Academy, William C. Overfelt Electronics Academy, Piedmont Hills CAD Pathway, Piedmont Hills Entrepreneurship Pathway, Piedmont Hills Carpentry Pathway, Oak Grove Travel and Tourism Academy, Oak Grove International Cuisine Pathway, Silver Creek Business Careers Pathway, Silver Creek Telecommunications Pathway, Yerba Buena Automotive, Yerba Buena Green Construction Academy, Yerba Buena Pre-Engineering Pathway, Independence Academy of Finance, Independence Engineering Space Science Pathway, Independence Carpentry, Independence teaching Academy, and the Santa Teresa Multimedia Pathway.Program Support:Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in the Arts, Media and Entertainment Industry Sector, the Building Trades and Construction Industry Sector, Education, Child Development and Family Services Industry, Energy and Utilities Industry Sector, Engineering and Design Industry Sector, Finance and Business Industry Sector, Health, Science and Medical Technology Industry Sector, Hospitality, Tourism and Recreation Industry Sector, Transportation Industry Sector and the Public Services Industry Sector.  Funds will also be used to support certificated FTE for courses that will be offered for the first time at Andrew Hill, William C. Overfelt, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove and Independence High Schools.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006 Section 131RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 131 Grant 2010-11 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education Program.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Cari Vaeth, Director of Adult Education and Career ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2010-11 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education ProgramOverview:The East Side Adult Education Program is part of a six program Career Technical Education consortium to receive Carl Perkins funding.  Under its guidelines adult education agencies who can not generate $50,000 in grant funding may apply for funding under a consortium model.  The four partners in the consortium are Metropolitan Adult Education, Campbell Union High School District, Mountain View-Los Altos Adult Education, Santa Clara Adult Education, and Sunnyvale-Cupertino Adult Education.  With the assistance of our consortium members, the East Side Adult Education has served as the lead partner in this consortium and is charged with submitting the application, monitoring the progress toward goal achievement, and evaluating the Carl Perkins plan annually.Accomplishments:Utilizing information for Central Santa Clara County from the Employment Development Department, input from the five Adult Education Program Advisory Committees, and staff and student surveys, the CTE Consortium Advisory Committee identified two industry sectors and related career pathways addressed in this five year plan.  Perkins funds will be used to assist programs in Health and Science which will focus on Clinical Nursing, Medical Assistant, and Home Health Aide Assistant career pathways.  The second industry sector is Information Technology, which will focus on Administrative Assistant, Database Administrator, Support & Services Technician, Desktop Publishing, and Accounting career pathways.  The Adult Education Programs in the consortium offer a thriving program for the completion of a secondary education and English language development and providing career learning opportunities in health, medicine, and information technology that have numerous entry and advancements options will complement our programs. FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Improvement Act of 2006,Section 132RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Carl D. Perkins 132 Grant 2010-11 Grant Application for East Side Adult Education Program.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Adopt Resolution #2009/2010-42 Declaring April 27, 2010, as School Bus Driver DayEach year, the California State Assembly recognizes the hard work and dedicated service provided by California School Bus Drivers. The State of California declares the fourth Tuesday in April as School Bus Driver Day in California.  As we celebrate School Bus Driver Day, take a moment to thank a school bus driver for their service to your community. FISCAL IMPACT:N/AFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended the Board of Trustees Adopt Resolution #2009/2010-42 Declaring April 27, 2010, as School Bus Driver Day.EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTDeclaring April 27, 2010School Bus Driver DayResolution #2009/2010-42WHEREAS, The safety of our children rests in the hands of trained school bus drivers for up to two to three hours each school day, and,WHEREAS, Great amounts of personal time and energy for bus driver's initial training and maintaining current licensing, skills and knowledge of school bus laws through continuing education classes are expended by drivers, and,WHEREAS, School bus drivers often face natural and unnatural hazards in the performance of their duties, and,WHEREAS, School bus drivers frequently assist students in learning and growing in appropriate interactive peer and adult behaviors through counseling and/or disciplinary techniques, and,WHEREAS, School bus drivers consistently demonstrate patience and kindness toward students, parents and school staff in the performance of their duties, and,WHEREAS, School bus drivers consistently demonstrate an awareness of and direct attention to school bus and school bus routes, mechanical and safety conditions respectively, and,WHEREAS, Many school bus drivers perform their services for thousands and thousands of accident free miles, year after year,THEREFORE, BE IT HEREBY RESOLVED, that the People of the State of California officially recognize and laud all of CALIFORNIA'S SCHOOL BUS DRIVERS on the fourth Tuesday of April, annually, for their continued and excellent services to the youth of the State.PASSED AND ADOPTED this 15th day of April 2010 by the Governing Board of the East Side Union High School District at its regular meeting held at 830 N. Capitol Avenue, San Jose, State of California. AYES:   ________NOES:  ________ABSENT:  ______ABSTAIN:  ______I certify the foregoing resolution was duly introduced, passed, and adopted by the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees at a meeting held on April 15, 2010._________________________Patricia Martinez-Roach, ClerkESUHSD Board of Trustees

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Jerry Kurr, Associate Superintendent of Administration and Business ServicesSUBJECT:Approve Contracts for Professional Services over $50,000The following Contracts for Professional Services over $50,000 is being recommended for Board approval.1.  Kleinfelder Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerJerry KurrJohn LawrenceDonna BertrandJanuary 22, 2010 through and including January 21, 2011$53,484.00School Facilities FundEducation CenterJerry KurrJohn LawrenceThe District is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to issue Amendment #1 to Contract Services Agreement and Change Order #1 to Purchase Order #002183, with Kleinfelder for the contract term January 22, 2010, through and including January 21, 2011.  Services are for the provision of special inspection, materials and testing services related to the installation of photovoltaic systems at the six listed high schools and other related services as needed.  Contractor will also provide geotechnical observation and consultation during construction of solar panels drilled pier foundations at the six listed high schools and other related services as needed.Schools include Andrew Hill, Evergreen Valley, Foothill, Independence, Santa Teresa, and W. C. Overfelt.Reason for the Amendment/Change OrderThe original Contract Services Agreements were approved by the Board of Trustees at the January 18, 2010, Board meeting in the amount of $52,975 and $13,800 for a total of $66,775.  The original contracts were based on a set of assumptions regarding the production schedule to manufacturing the T-Structures and the written requirements from DSA.  However, since that time, the production schedule has slipped, which has delayed the project and DSA has added additional requirements significantly increasing the number of inspections.Selection Process The process was completed under the original Board approval of January 21, 2010. Three consultants were solicited and Kleinfelder was selected based on their rates being the lowest of the three proposals.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Amendment #1 to Contract Services Agreement and Change Order #1 to Purchase Order #002183, with Kleinfelder for the contract term January 22, 2010, through and including January 21, 2011.  Services are for the provision of special inspection, materials and testing services related to the installation of photovoltaic systems at the six listed high schools and other related services as needed. Contractor will also provide Geotechnical Observation and consultation during construction of solar panels drilled pier foundations at the six listed high schools and other related services as needed. 2.  Verde Design, Inc.   Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerA. GarofaloJ. Rono, Ph.D.D. BertrandApril 16, 2010 through and including June 30, 2012$74,250.00 (which includes 10% for expenses)Measure EEducation CenterAlan GarofaloJune Rono, Ph.D.East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a Work Authorization Agreement with Verde Design, Inc. for the term of April 16, 2010 through June 30, 2012, for the provision of Architectural Design Services for the James Lick High School Title IX Field Improvement Project.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.This project is the result of recent site priority evaluation pertaining to Title IX compliance, as was earlier identified in the Bond Program budget presentation.  The project has been determined to be an immediate need, due to safety and equity concerns.  Also clarified during the budget presentation is the understanding that the funding of this effort is available from the uncommitted campus allocation, and has been approved as a priority by the Principal, Glenn VanderZee.One overriding consideration is to maintain the reliable level of design and construction results that have been realized across the District, including James Lick High School.  Verde Design, Inc. has been retained for the majority of recent field and outdoor athletic facility work with the District.Selection Process Verde Design, Inc. has proven to be a qualified consultant and designer, specializing in field design work, and is the only A/E firm in the qualified pool specializing in athletic fields.  ESUHSD has employed their services for several other field, scoreboard, and dugout projects.  The project schedules and budgets have been adhered to, with satisfactory results.  This project was developed quickly out of a recent Title IX compliance and safety concern, thus necessitating the selection of a known, qualified consultant.RECOMMENDATION:This item is contingent on the approval of revised Measure E budget, presented as item 14.03.  It is recommended that the Board of Trustees enter into a Work Authorization Agreement with Verde Design, Inc. for the term of April 16, 2010, through June 30, 2012, for the provision of architectural design services for the James Lick High School Title IX Field Improvement Project. 3.  Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerA. GarofaloJ. Rono, Ph.D.D. BertrandApril 16, 2010 through and including April 15, 2013$427,500.00Measure EEducation CenterCalero SchoolAlan GarofaloJune Rono, Ph.D.East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a Contract for Construction Management Services for Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. for the Calero High School Modernization Project. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero project as defined in item 10.01.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.N/ASelection Process The District completed a formal Request for Qualifications (RFQ), RFQ-02-08-09, which went to the Board for approval of the recommended “Measure E & G Pre-Approved Construction Management Firms (CM) List” on March 10, 2009.  With this list in place, the District then requests from all four of the pre-approved firms to submit a “Construction Management Selection Questionnaire (CMSQ)” which will include the cost and project team being proposed.  In this case, back on June 9, 2009, Facilities requested CMSQ from three of the four firms.  At that time Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc. was selected to be recommended to the Board for approval.  However, at that time and at subsequent meetings this project was removed from the Board agenda.For this Board meeting, purchasing requested that new proposals be obtained due to the age of the old proposals and the fact that the hard cost had increased significantly which would affect the cost proposals previously submitted.  Facilities was able to secure two new proposals but the third vendor was not able to provide a new proposal “given the time frame in which it is required”.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees enter into an Agreement with Facilities Management Planning and Operations, Inc., for the Term April 16, 2010 through and including April 15, 2013, for the Provision of Construction Management Services for the Calero High School Modernization Project contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero Project as defined in item 10.01. 4.  Sugimura Finney Architects Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerA. GarofaloJ. Rono, Ph.D.D. BertrandApril 16, 2010 through and including April 15, 2013$641,250.00Measure EEducation CenterCalero SchoolAlan GarofaloJune Rono, Ph.D.East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to enter into a Work Authorization Agreement for Architectural Design Services with Sugimura Finney Architects for the Calero High School Modernization Project. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero Project as defined in item 10.01.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.N/ASelection Process The District completed a formal Request for Qualifications (RFQ), RFQ-03-07-08, which went to the Board for approval of the recommended pool of District Architects on June 19, 2008. With this list in place, the District requested three Architectural firms to provide an “Architect Selection Questionnaire (ASQ)” which includes a cost and project team proposal.  In this case, back on June 9, 2009, Facilities requested ASQ’s from three firms.  At that time Sugimura Finney Architects was selected to be recommended to the Board for approval.  However, at that time and at subsequent meetings this project was removed from the Board agenda.For this Board meeting, Purchasing Department requested that new proposals be obtained due to the age of the old proposals and the fact that the hard cost had increased significantly which would affect the cost proposals previously submitted.  New proposals were obtained and Sugimura Finney Architects is still the recommended Architect based on the new proposals obtained.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees enter into a Work Authorization Agreement for Architectural Design Services with Sugimura Finney Architects for the Calero High School Modernization Project for the term of April 16, 2010, through and including April 15, 2013. This approval is contingent upon the Board authorizing Facilities to move forward with the Calero Project as defined in item 10.01. 5.  Pine Hill School  Reviewed by:Contract PeriodCost/Fund SourceSchool/Dept. ManagerC. HersomD. BertrandJuly 1, 2009 through and including June 30, 2010$250,000.00 (increase amount)TuitionEducation CenterSpecial ServicesCarole HersomThe District is requesting authorization from the Board of Trustees to issue Amendment #1 to Contract Services Agreement and Change Order #1 to Purchase Order #001057, with Pine Hill School for the contract term July 1, 2009, through and including June 30, 2010.  Services are for the provision of Special Education Services to East Side Union High School District special education students per their IEP requirements.Reason for the Purchase of Outside Services.The original Contract Services Agreements were approved by the Board of Trustees at the August 20, 2009 Board meeting in the amount of $205,659.20.  The original Contracts were based on a specific number of students who had already been placed at Pine Hill School.  However, since that time, the number of students referred and placed at Pine Hill School has increased and the funding needs to increase in order to pay for the services to be provided to these additional students.Selection Process No solicitation process has taken place either at the initiation of this contract nor at this time.  Students are referred and placed to alternative schools based on IEP hearings.  ESUHSD is required to pay the school portion of the placement.  Therefore, no solicitation process can take place for these types of placements.RECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Amendment #1 to Contract Services Agreement and Change Order #1 to Purchase Order #001057, with Pine Hill School for the contract term July 1, 2009, through and including June 30, 2010.  Services are for the provision of Special Education Services to East Side Union High School District special education students per their IEP requirements.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and Glenn VanderZee, Principal, James Lick High SchoolSUBJECT:Approve Participation for Earth Day Network Project at James Lick High SchoolOverview:Earth Day Network is a non-profit organization that provides a voluntary Green/Solar Program to public schools at no cost.  James Lick High School has been selected as another school to participate in an Earth Day Network Project.The James Lick High School and Earth Day Network partnership will be an educational endeavor and a project to enhance James Lick High School’s efforts to teach and move towards sustainability.  Specifically, this project will include the installation of an Earth Day Network donated, no-cost photovoltaic solar panel system.  This system will also include an educational monitoring display that includes an individual website where students, teachers, and administrators can utilize the system’s performance via consistent updates for educational benefit.  Earth Day Network will be responsible for the financial aspects of this project and it will be completed at no cost to James Lick High School or the District.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve James Lick High School’s participation in this very worthwhile endeavor.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Dan Moser, Interim SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and Facilities, and June Francis Rono, Ph.D., Director of Facilities and Planning SUBJECT:Approve Proposed Measure E Bond Program Budget Reconciliation and Status Review of Current ProjectsThe voters in the East Side Union High School District approved the Measure E General Obligation Bond in February, 2008. The first funds for Measure E were sold in May of 2008. The Board of Trustees approved a detailed Measure E Bond Program Master Budget in February, 2009. Modifications to project scope and attendant budgets have been brought to the Board for consideration and approval in the ensuing period - including June 2009, August 2009, and September 2009. A combination of economic conditions and these periodic adjustments have had an impact on the internal consistency of the overall Master Measure E Program Budget.Aggressive schedule management has also enabled concurrent launch of over 30 projects, allowing the District to take full advantage of the exceptional bidding climate and create as many new jobs as possible in the regional market. Additionally, the Facilities and Planning Division will continue to apply for State modernization funds to provide greater leverage to our existing Bond Program. A status review of current projects will accompany consideration of this item.The Facilities and Planning Division will review the Measure E Master Budget on an ongoing basis as a means of sustaining an aggressive approach to the delivery of projects under the Measure E Bond Program, allowing the District to leverage Bond dollars to the maximum extent, while exercising best fiscal practices.The Facilities Bond Team will be present to answer questions from the Board of Trustees.FISCAL IMPACT:   No fiscal impact change.  Measure E budget reconciliation only. FUNDING SOURCE:Measure ERECOMMENDATION: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the proposed  Measure  E Revised Bond Program Budget.
